ingredient.name: Inulin
ingredient.description: Inulin is a type of soluble fiber and prebiotic found naturally in many plants, particularly chicory root and Jerusalem artichoke. It acts as a prebiotic by selectively stimulating the growth and activity of beneficial bacteria in the colon, particularly Bifidobacterium species. Inulin is not digested by human enzymes but is fermented by gut bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids that provide various health benefits.

dosage_info.timing: with meals to reduce GI distress
dosage_info.notes: Start with lower dose and gradually increase to minimize bloating

ingredient.safety_notes: Generally safe for most adults. May cause gas, bloating, or digestive discomfort in sensitive individuals, especially at higher doses. Start with small amounts and increase gradually. Those with FODMAP sensitivity should consult healthcare provider.

microbiome_effects.mechanism: Provides fermentable substrate that is preferentially utilized by Bifidobacterium species
Secondary fermentation of inulin breakdown products supports Lactobacillus growth

metabolic_effects.mechanism: Bacterial fermentation of inulin produces butyrate, acetate, and propionate
SCFA production lowers colonic pH, enhancing calcium solubility and absorption

symptom_effects.population_notes: More effective in elderly populations and those with chronic constipation
More common in individuals with IBS or FODMAP sensitivity

citations.title: Prebiotic effects of inulin and oligofructose
citations.authors: Gibson GR, Hutkins R, Sanders ME, Prescott SL, Reimer RA, Salminen SJ, Scott K, Stanton C, Swanson KS, Cani PD, Verbeke K, Reid G

citations.title: Inulin supplementation modulates the gut microbiota and increases butyrate-producing bacteria
citations.authors: Ramirez-Farias C, Slezak K, Fuller Z, Duncan A, Holtrop G, Louis P

interactions.effect_description: Inulin and probiotics work synergistically as a synbiotic combination, with inulin providing substrate for probiotic bacteria
